conclusion: There are not enough monitoring stations with sufficient data to assess status and/or trends within the Burnt River AgWQ Management Area to understand the spatial homogeneity of the basin.
Additional data is needed to evaluate site potential vegetation on the agricultural land, which would require remote sensing data to determine tree heights and calculate effective shade

No monitoring stations have sufficient data to calculate the 7DADM for temperature and assess against the applicable water quality standards. Additional continuous temperature, dissolved oxygen and pH data would be useful in the AgWQ management are to better understand in-stream diurnal fluctuations.

One monitoring station within the Burnt River AgWQ Management Area has sufficient data to assess water quality status and trends for dissolved oxygen. Results were compared to the applicable water quality standard. Monitoring station 11494 had a significant degrading trend and no exceedances of the water quality standard within the last two years of assess data.

One monitoring station within the Burnt River AgWQ Management Area has sufficient data to assess water quality status and trends for E. coli. Results were compared to the water quality standard. Monitoring station 11494 had a significant degrading (positive) trend and exceedances of the water quality standard within the last two years of assess data.

One monitoring station within the Burnt River AgWQ Management Area has sufficient data to assess water quality status and trends for pH. Results were compared to the applicable water quality standard. Monitoring station 11494 had a significant positive trend and no exceedances of the water quality standard within the last two years of assess data.

There are no monitoring stations within the Burnt River AgWQ Management Area with sufficient data to calculate the 7DADM and assess the data against the applicable State Water Quality Standard. Continuous data is needed to calculate the 7DADM.

Eight monitoring stations within the Burnt River AgWQ Management Area have sufficient data to assess water quality status and/or trends for total phosphorus, relative to the Snake River Hells Canyon 2004 TMDL allocation. Station 11494 has sufficient data to assess water quality status and trends, there are exceedances of the allocation within the last two years and there is not a significant trend. Seven monitoring stations have sufficient data to assess water quality status of total phosphorus, two monitoring stations do not have exceedances within the last two years (1119U-WQX-POW146 and 1119U-WQX-POW162), all other stations have at least one exceedance of the load allocation.

One monitoring station has sufficient data to assess water quality trends of total suspended solids in the Burnt River AgWQ Management Area. Station 11494 does not have a significant trend and there is no applicable TMDL load allocation to assess status.

No monitoring stations have sufficient data to calculate the 7DADM for temperature and assess against the applicable water quality standards. Additional continuous temperature, dissolved oxygen and pH data would be useful in the AgWQ management are to better understand in-stream diurnal fluctuations.

Additional data is needed to evaluate the surrogate site potential vegetation on the agricultural land, which would require remote sensing data to determine tree heights and calculate effective shade against the proposed continuous water quality data and focused restoration areas.

Two monitoring stations have sufficient data to assess water quality status and/or trends of dissolved oxygen within the Crooked River AgWQ Management Area. Monitoring station 10517 does not have exceedances of the water quality standard within the last two years, station 11477 as at least one exceedance. Neither of the monitoring stations has a significant trend.

There are four monitoring stations within the Crooked River AgWQ Management that have sufficient data to assess status and/or trends of E. coli. One monitoring station (Station ID: 10517) has at least one exceedance of the water quality standard within the last two years and a significant degrading trend. Monitoring station 11477 does not have exceedances of the water quality standard within the last two years, but a significant degrading trend. Monitoring stations 1119USBR_WQX-CRO002 and 1119USBR_WQX-CRO128 do not have significant trends and do not have exceedances of the water quality standard within the last two years.

Two monitoring stations have sufficient data to evaluate status and/or trends of pH within the Crooked River AgWQ Management Area. Both monitoring stations (Station ID: 10517 & 11477) have exceedances of the water quality standard within the last two years and a significant negative trend. For both monitoring stations, all exceedances are basic and occur throughout the entire timeframe.

There are no monitoring stations within the Crooked River AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient data to calculate the 7DADM and evaluate against the applicable water quality standard. Continuous temperature data is needed to calculate the 7DADM.

Two monitoring stations have sufficient data to assess water quality trends of total phosphorus within the Crooked River AgWQ Management Area (Station ID: 10517 and 11477). Station 10517 has a significant steady trend. Stations 1119USBR_WQX-CRO002 and 1119USBR_WQX-CRO128 have sufficient data to make a qualitative assessment of the status of water quality in regards to total phosphorus concentrations.

Two monitoring stations have sufficient data to assess water quality trends of total suspended solids within the Crooked River AgWQ Management Area (Station ID: 10517 and 11477). Station 10517 has a significant degrading (positive) trend. Stations 1119USBR_WQX-CRO002 and 1119USBR_WQX-CRO128 have sufficient data to make a qualitative assessment of the status of water quality in regards to total suspended solids concentrations.

Little data exists in the Greater Harney Basin AgWQ Management Area to assess water quality status and trends. There is no continuous temperature data from 2001 forward, which gives little insight into natural and anthropogenic contributions to water temperature.
Continuous temperature, dissolved oxygen, and pH data would be useful in this AgWQ Management Area in order to understand diurnal fluctuations.
Additional data is needed to evaluate site potential vegetation on the agricultural land, which would require remote sensing data to determine tree heights and calculate effective shade.

Two monitoring stations (12264 and 33929) had sufficient grab sample data to assess water quality status and trends in the Greater Harney Basin AgWQ Management Area. Station 12264 had no exceedances of the water quality standard from 2000 to 2017 and an insignificant trend. Station 33929 had one exceedance of the water quality standard throughout the entire timeframe (2006-2017) and an insignificant trend.

Two monitoring stations (12264 and 33929) had data from 2012 ? 2016 and therefore sufficient data to assess water quality status, but not enough to assess trends in bacteria. Monitoring station 33929 had no exceedances of the water quality standard from 2012 to 2016, while station 12264 had multiple exceedances during the entire timeframe. There was not enough data to calculate the geometric mean for either monitoring station.

Two monitoring stations (12264 and 33929) had sufficient data to assess water quality status and trends in pH within the Greater Harney Basin AgWQ Management Area. Both stations had insignificant trends and no exceedances of the water quality standard during the timeframe.

No monitoring stations have recent continuous data, sufficient to calculate the 7DADM. Monitoring station 12264 had sufficient data to calculate the 7DADM for temperature in 2000 and 2001, but not since.

One monitoring station (12264) had sufficient data assess trends in total phosphorus within the Greater Harney Basin AgWQ Management Area and it had a significant degrading (positive) trend. Station 33929 had data from 2006 ? 2017 but not enough unique years of data to calculate trend.

One monitoring station (12264) had sufficient data assess trends in total suspended solids within the Greater Harney Basin AgWQ Management Area and it had a significant degrading (positive) trend. Station 33929 had data from 2006 ? 2017 but not enough unique years of data to calculate trend.

No stations within the Middle Deschutes AgWQ Management Area have continuous data for pH and dissolved oxygen. Continuous data is necessary to calculate the 7DADM and assess the data with regards to the water quality standard. Having continuous data is beneficial in understanding in-stream diurnal fluctuations. One monitoring station on the Deschutes River has continuous data, sufficient for the calculation of the 7DADM for temperature.
Additional data is needed to evaluate site potential vegetation on the agricultural land, which would require remote sensing data to determine tree heights and calculate effective shade.
There are not enough monitoring stations with sufficient data to assess status and/or trends within the Middle Deschutes AgWQ Management Area to understand the spatial homogeneity of the basin.

There are two monitoring stations within the Middle Deschutes AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient data to assess status and/or trends of dissolved oxygen data with regards to the applicable water quality standard. Both stations had at least one exceedance of the water quality standard within the two most recent years of data assessed. Station 10506 had enough data to assess trends in the data, but there was not a significant trend. Station 36776 did not have enough data to assess water quality trends. Only grab sample dissolved oxygen data was available.

There are two monitoring stations within the Middle Deschutes AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient data to assess status and/or trends of E. coli data. Results were assessed using the Oregon water quality standard for E. coli concentrations. Monitoring station 10506 did not have exceedances of the water quality standard within the last two years of assessed data and had a significant steady trend (slope of zero). Station 36776 had at least one exceedance of the water quality standard within the last two years of assessed data and not enough years of data to assess trends.

There are two monitoring stations within the Middle Deschutes AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient data to assess status and/or trends of pH data with regards to the applicable water quality standard. Both stations had at least one exceedance of the water quality standard within the two most recent years of data assessed. Station 10506 had enough data to assess trends in the data, but there was not a significant trend. Station 36776 did not have enough data to assess water quality trends. Only grab sample pH data was available.

One monitoring station within the Middle Deschutes AgWQ Management Area has sufficient data to calculate the 7DADM and assess the results against the applicable water quality standard. Within the last two years of recent data, there are exceedances of the water quality standard.

There are two monitoring stations with the Middle Deschutes AgWQ Management Area with sufficient data to assess water quality trends. There is no water quality standard or applicable TMDL load allocation to assess total phosphorus within the Middle Deschutes AgWQ Management Area. Station 10506 had a significant steady trend (slope equals zero), station 36776 did not have enough data to perform a trends analysis.

There are two monitoring stations with the Middle Deschutes AgWQ Management Area with sufficient data to assess water quality trends. There is no water quality standard or applicable TMDL load allocation to assess total suspended solids within the Middle Deschutes AgWQ Management Area. Station 10506 did not have a statistically significant trend in the data, station 36776 did not have enough data to perform a trends analysis.

Although all 5 stations fit the decision criteria (Figure 2), there are not enough monitoring stations with sufficient data to assess status and/or trends within the Middle Willamette AgWQ Management Area to understand the spatial homogeneity of the basin.

No monitoring stations have sufficient data to calculate the 7DADM for temperature and assess against the applicable water quality standards. Additional continuous temperature, dissolved oxygen and pH data would be useful in the AgWQ management are to better understand in-stream diurnal fluctuations. Additional data is needed to evaluate the surrogate site potential vegetation on the agricultural land, which would require remote sensing data to determine tree heights and calculate effective shade against the proposed continuous water quality data and focused restoration areas.

Five monitoring stations have sufficient data to fit the criteria to assess water quality status and/or trends of dissolved oxygen, relative to the applicable Oregon water quality standard. Two monitoring stations have sufficient data to assess trends (11140 and 10373). Station 10373 has a significant improving trend, while station 11140 does not have a significant trend. All monitoring stations have at least one exceedance of the water quality standard within the last two years.

Four monitoring stations within the Middle Willamette AgWQ Management Area have sufficient data to fit the criteria to assess water quality status and/or trends of E. coli, relative to the Oregon water quality standard. The fifth station, 37103 does not collect samples for E coli. Two monitoring stations (11140 and 10373) have sufficient data to determine trends, though both sites do not have significant trends. Stations 36875 and 36790 do not have exceedances of the water quality standard within the last two years while stations 11140 and 10373 have at least one exceedance.

Five monitoring stations have sufficient data to fit the criteria to assess water quality status and/or trends of pH, relative to the applicable Oregon water quality standard. Two monitoring stations have sufficient data to assess trends (11140 and 10373). Station 11140 has a significant positive trend, while station 10373 does not have a significant trend. All monitoring stations meet the water quality standard within the last two years.
Although monitoring stations met the decision criteria ( Figure 2 ), no monitoring stations have sufficient data to calculate the 7DADM and assess water quality status and trends of temperature.

Five monitoring stations within the Middle Willamette AgWQ Management Area have sufficient data to assess water quality status, though there is no total phosphorus TMDL load allocation to compare the data to. Stations 11140 and 10373 have sufficient data to assess trends in data, though neither are significant (Table 6).

Four monitoring stations within the Middle Willamette AgWQ Management Area have sufficient data to assess water quality status; though there is no total suspended solids TMDL load allocation to compare the data to. The fifth station, 37103, does not collect samples for TSS. Stations 11140 and 10373 have sufficient data to assess trends in data, station 11140 has a significant positive (degrading) trend, and station 10373 does not have a significant trend (Table 6).

Although total suspended solid concentrations were classified as degrading at 5 of 18 stations, observed concentrations at these stations were very low. Degrading trends at these stations were marginal (i.e., the slopes of these trend lines were close to 0). Although statistically significant, these trends are likely the result of having a high number of observations at these stations, rather than a meaningful lessening of water quality at these stations.

Grab samples may not provide a complete characterization of water quality for parameters that fluctuate on a daily basis (e.g., temperature, DO, pH). For this reason continuous data are preferred and should be considered when monitoring these parameters in the future.

This report is best used as a summary and statistical analysis of the status and trends in water quality data collected throughout the North Coast AgWQ Management Area. Interpretation of results will require knowledge of local conditions known to affect the observed water quality conditions at individual sites.

Data collected at 16 stations were sufficient to assess dissolved oxygen concentration water quality status and 19 stations for trends. Dissolved oxygen concentrations observed at 10 stations exceeded the water quality standard within the last two years. Observed trends were mixed, with 9 stations improving, 1 station degrading, and the remaining 9 stations with no statistically significant trend.

There were 15 monitoring stations within the North Coast AgWQ Management that had sufficient data to assess status and trends in E. coli concentration. One monitoring station (Station ID: 13440, Tillamook River at Bewley Creek Rd.) had at least one exceedance of the water quality standard within the last two years, but had a significant improving trend. Five monitoring stations (10523, 13417, 13424, 13433, 34019) do not have exceedances of the water quality standard within the last two years, but a significant degrading trend. The remaining nine monitoring stations do not have exceedances of the water quality standard and do not exhibit significant trends within the last 15 years.

Data collected at 11 stations were sufficient to assess Enterococcus concentration water quality status and 18 stations for trends. Enterococcus concentrations observed at 7 of the 11 stations exceeded the water quality standard within the last two years. Observed trends were mixed, with  two stations that exceed the standard degrading (34725 and 36221), seven stations holding steady, and one station improving.

Data collected at 15 stations were sufficient to evaluate pH status and at 19 stations for trends of pH within the North Coast AgWQ Management Area. Only 3 monitoring stations (10817, 11434, and 12187) had exceedances of the water quality standard within the last two years. Trends at 11 of the 19 stations with sufficient data were degrading. One station (13429) had an improving trend.

There were no monitoring stations within the North Coast AgWQ Management Area that had sufficient data to calculate status (7DADM) and evaluate against the applicable water quality standard. Only station (21811 - Ben Smith Creek at River Mile 0.44) had sufficient data to determine trends. This station had a degrading trend.

Data collected at 19 stations were sufficient to evaluate trends in total phosphorous concentration. Three stations (10812, 13428,  and 13429) had a statistically significant improving trend. The remaining 16 stations did not have a significant trend.

Data collected at 18 stations were sufficient to evaluate trends in total suspended solids. Two stations (13428 and 13429) had a statistically significant improving trend, five stations (10812, 10817, 12187, 13424, and 13433) had a statistically significant degrading trend, and three stations had a steady trend. The remaining eight stations did not have a significant trend.
Additional data is needed to evaluate site potential vegetation on the agricultural land, which would require remote sensing data to determine tree heights and calculate effective shade.
Monitoring stations with sufficient data to assess status and/or trends do not display spatial homogeneity within the subbasin.

Several sites on the Powder River have continuous temperature data from 2013, which isnÂt available in the queried databases. The Powder Basin Watershed Council also collected water quality data, recent data is not included in this report.

Included in the databases in this report, there are no monitoring stations that contain sufficient data (continuous data) to calculate the seven-day-average-daily-maximum which is necessary to compare to the water quality standard for temperature.

Included in the databases in this report, continuous data for dissolved oxygen, temperature, and pH would be useful in understanding diurnal fluctuations and patterns. The continuous data for these parameters collected by DEQ in 2014 and 2015 for use in TMDL development are not included in this report.

Two monitoring stations have sufficient data to assess status and trends of dissolved oxygen in the Powder-Brownlee AgWQ Management Area (10724 and 11490). Both monitoring stations are in compliance of the water quality standard within the last two years of analyzed data (2014-2017) and both stations have statistically insignificant trends over the timeframe (2000-2017). Continuous dissolved oxygen data, which is not included in this report, resulted in spawning season dissolved oxygen listings.

Two monitoring stations have sufficient data to assess water quality status and trends (10724 and 11490) for E. coli. Both monitoring stations have exceedances within the last two years of analyzed data (2014-2017) and an insignificant trend throughout the entire timeframe (2000-2017).

Two monitoring stations (10724 and 11490) have sufficient data to assess water quality status and for pH within the Powder-Brownlee AgWQ Management Area. Both monitoring stations are in compliance of the water quality standard within the last two years of analyzed data trends (2014-2017). Monitoring station 10724 has a significant improving slope (slope near 0), while monitoring station 11490 has an insignificant trend.

No monitoring stations have recent continuous data, sufficient to calculate the 7DADM within the data that is currently available in public and DEQ (Element and LASAR) databases. The Powder Basin Watershed Council collected water quality data, which is not included in the report. DEQ also collected continuous temperature data in 2013 which is not in this report.

Two monitoring stations have sufficient data to assess status trends in total phosphorus within the Powder-Brownlee AgWQ Management Area (10724 and 11490). Both stations have insignificant trends throughout the timeframe (2000-2017).  Both monitoring stations have many results that are not in compliance with the TMDL load allocation (0.07 mg/l) and are in exceedance of the allocation within the last two years of available data.

Two monitoring stations have sufficient data to assess status and trends in total suspended solids within the Powder-Brownlee AgWQ Management Area (10724 and 11490). Both stations have insignificant trends throughout the timeframe (2000-2017). Though both monitoring stations have exceedances of the TMDL load allocation (50 mg/l), they are in compliance within the last two years of available data.
Additional data is needed to evaluate site potential vegetation on the agricultural land, which would require remote sensing data to determine tree heights and calculate effective shade.
All monitoring stations with sufficient data to assess status and/or trends of temperature had exceedances of the water quality standard throughout the analyzed timeframe (2000-2017).

There are thirteen monitoring stations within the Tualatin River Subbasin AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient dissolved oxygen results to assess the overall water quality status and trends relative to the applicable water quality standard. Seven monitoring stations have continuous dissolved oxygen data, six monitoring stations have grab sample dissolved oxygen data. One monitoring station (10461) has data in compliance of the water quality standard within the last two years of analyzed data, all other stations have at least one exceedance during that time. Station 10459 has a significant improving trend, three monitoring stations (USGS 14202980, USGS 453030122560101, and USGS 14206694) have significant degrading trends.

There are six monitoring stations with the Tualatin River Subbasin AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient E. coli results to assess overall water quality status, 42 stations have sufficient data to assess trends. Four monitoring stations (10480, 10469, 10459, and 10459) have at least one exceedance of the water quality standard within the last two years of analyze data. Seven monitoring stations have significant improving trends, eight have significant degrading trends, and 27 have insignificant trends. All stations with improving or degrading trends are monitored and collected by the USGS.

There are fifteen monitoring stations within the Tualatin River Subbasin AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient pH results to assess the overall water quality status, 46 monitoring stations have sufficient data to assess water quality trends. Five monitoring stations have significant negative trends, 21 monitoring stations have significant positive trends, and 20 monitoring stations do not have a significant trend. Of the stations with recent data to assess status, 14 meet the water quality standard within the last two years, one (USGS 14205400) has at least one exceedance within the last two years.

There are ten monitoring stations with the Tualatin River Subbasin AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient temperature results to assess overall water quality status and trends and calculate the seven day daily maximum. All stations have at least one exceedance of the applicable water quality standard within the last two years of analyzed data.

There are 27 monitoring stations within the Tualatin River Subbasin AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient data to assess total phosphorus status (recent two years, results from summer) in relation to the TMDL loading capacity concentrations. Six monitoring stations have sufficient data to assess trends in total phosphorus throughout all seasons. Station 10469 had a significant steady trend while all other stations did not have significant trends.

There are six monitoring stations within the Tualatin River Subbasin AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient total suspended solids results to assess water quality and trends, status cannot be assessed since there is no TMDL load allocation. Two stations (10461 and 10459) have significant degrading (positive) trends, all other stations do not have significant trends.
Continued data collection of dissolved oxygen and pH will allow for the assessment of trends in the future

There are many stations with water quality data within the Upper Deschutes AgWQ Management Area. An increase of continuous data for temperature, dissolved oxygen, and pH will be useful to view diurnal fluctuations within the data.
Additional data is needed to evaluate site potential vegetation on the agricultural land, which would require remote sensing data to determine tree heights and calculate effective shade.

There are 34 monitoring stations within the Upper Deschutes AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient data to assess the overall status of dissolved oxygen in relation to the applicable water quality standard; six stations have sufficient data to assess status and trends of dissolved oxygen. Ten monitoring stations have at least one exceedance of the water quality standard within the most recent two years of analyzed data. Monitoring station 10511 has a significant improving trend, all other stations have no significant trends.

There are six stations within the Upper Deschutes AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient data to assess status and/or trends of E. coli in relation to the State water quality standard. Within the last two years of analyzed data, all stations met the water quality standard. Station 10686 has a significant degrading (positive) trend, station 10688 has a significant steady trend (slope of zero), and all other stations have no significant trend.

There are 33 monitoring stations within the Upper Deschutes AgWQ Management Area with sufficient data to assess water quality status in relation to the State water quality standard; six monitoring stations have sufficient data to assess water quality status and trends. Six monitoring stations had at least one exceedance of the water quality standard within the last two years of analyzed data, the rest of the stations were within the water quality standard values. One monitoring station has a significant positive trend (10508), station 10688 has a significant steady trend (slope = zero), the rest of the stations did not have a significant trend.

There are 17 monitoring stations within the Upper Deschutes AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient data to calculate the seven day average daily maximum and assess water quality last known status, none of the stations had sufficient data to assess temperature trends. All monitoring stations had exceedances of the applicable water quality standard within the last two years of analyzed data except USGS 14076500 and USGS 14087400.

There are 33 monitoring stations within the Upper Deschutes AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient data to assess status and trends of total phosphorus, though there is no total phosphorus TMDL within the basin and therefore only raw results are displayed in the report. No stations have significant trends.

There are 26 monitoring stations within the Upper Deschutes AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient data to assess status and trends of total suspended solids, though there is no total suspended solids TMDL within the basin and therefore only raw results are displayed in the report. No stations have significant trends.

Little data exists in the Walla Walla AgWQ Management Area that is sufficient to assess water quality status and trends. One monitoring station has sufficient data to assess water quality status for E. coli, pH, and dissolved oxygen. There is no continuous temperature data and therefore insufficient data to assess the temperature water quality status and trends in relation to the water quality standard and TMDL load allocations.
Additional data is needed to evaluate site potential vegetation on the agricultural land, which would require remote sensing data to determine tree heights and calculate effective shade.
The monitoring station with sufficient data to assess status and/or trends does not give a representative analysis of the Walla AgWQ Management Area
No monitoring stations that fit the criteria to assess status and/or trends have continuous dissolved oxygen pH, or temperature data, which is useful to understand the diurnal fluctuations.

One monitoring station had sufficient data to assess water quality status in relation to dissolved oxygen results in the Walla Walla AgWQ Management Area. Monitoring station 36786 has data from 2011-2017 and has exceedances of the dissolved oxygen water quality standard during that timeframe and within the last two years (2015-2017).

One monitoring station had sufficient data to assess water quality status in relation to E. coli results in the Walla Walla AgWQ Management Area. Monitoring station 36786 has data from 2011-2017 and has exceedances of the E. coli water quality standard during that timeframe and within the last two years (2015-2017).

One monitoring station had sufficient data to assess water quality status in relation to pH results in the Walla Walla AgWQ Management Area. Monitoring station 36786 has data from 2011-2017 and does not have any exceedances of the water quality standard during that timeframe.

There is insufficient data to calculate the seven day average daily maximum and therefore assess status and/or trends of temperature in the Walla Walla AgWQ Management Area. Continuous (sufficient for calculating was collected at multiple stations between 2000 and 2003), but since temperature grab samples have been collected (the 7DADM cannot be calculated from temperature grab samples). Since no monitoring stations have greater than eight years of continuous temperature data and/or recent data, there are no stations that fit the criteria to assess status and/or trends in the Walla Walla AgWQ Management Area. See the Interactive Status and Trends Document (Appendix) for complete list of monitoring stations and the number of results per year.

One monitoring station (36786) has total phosphorus data in the Walla Walla AgWQ Management Area. There is no TMDL in this basin and therefore the data is not compared to a standard or TMDL load allocation.

One monitoring station (36786) has total suspended solids data in the Walla Walla AgWQ Management Area. There is no TMDL in this basin and therefore the data is not compared to a standard or TMDL load allocation.

One monitoring station in the Wallowa AgWQ Management Area has long-term continuous temperature data, sufficient to calculate the 7DADM and assess against the applicable water quality standard. Additional continuous temperature, dissolved oxygen and pH data would be useful in the AgWQ management are to better understand in-stream diurnal fluctuations.
There are not enough monitoring stations with sufficient data to assess status and/or trends within the Wallowa AgWQ Management Area to understand the spatial homogeneity of the basin.
Additional data is needed to evaluate site potential vegetation on the agricultural land, which would require remote sensing data to determine tree heights and calculate effective shade.
Station 10410 has a some continuous data in 2001 for dissolved oxygen and pH.

There are three monitoring stations within the Wallowa AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient data to assess water quality status and/or trends of dissolved oxygen in relation to the applicable Oregon water quality standards. Monitoring stations 11457 and 35825 has exceedances of the water quality standard within the last two years of assessed data, while station 10410 meets the water quality standard within the last two years. Station 35825 only has grab data within the last two years while stations 11457 and 10410 have enough data to assess trends, which are insignificant.

There are two monitoring stations within the Wallowa AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient data to assess water quality status and/or trends of E. coli in relation to the Oregon water quality standards. Both monitoring stations (10410 and 11457) have significant degrading trends. Monitoring station 11457 is does not have any exceedances of the water quality standard within the last two years of assessed data, while monitoring station 10410 has at least an exceedance of the water quality standard within the last two years.

There are two monitoring stations within the Wallowa AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient data to assess water quality status and/or trends of pH in relation to the applicable Oregon water quality standards. Both statins meet the water quality standard within the last two years of assessed data. Monitoring station 11457 has a significant positive trend, monitoring station 10410 does not have a significant trend.

There is one monitoring station within the Wallowa AgWQ Management Area that has sufficient data to calculate the seven-day-average-daily maximum and assess the results in relation to the applicable water quality standard. The monitoring station, USGS-13331500, has exceedances of the water quality standard within the last two years of assessed data.

There are two monitoring stations within the Wallowa AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient data to assess total phosphorus trends. No total phosphorus TMDL load allocation exists within the Wallowa AgWQ Management Area. Monitoring station 11457 has a significant steady trend (slope equals zero); monitoring station 10410 has an insignificant trend. Monitoring station 35825 has grab sample data within the last two years.

There are two monitoring stations within the Wallowa AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient data to assess total suspended solids trends. No total suspended solid TMDL load allocation exists within the Wallowa AgWQ Management Area. Monitoring station 11457 has a significant steady trend (slope equals zero); monitoring station 10410 has an insignificant trend.
Monitoring stations with sufficient data to assess status and/or trends do not display spatial homogeneity within the Yamhill AgWQ Management Area.
No monitoring stations that fit the criteria to assess status and/or trends have continuous dissolved oxygen or pH data, which is useful to understand the diurnal fluctuations.
All monitoring stations with total phosphorus data have exceedances of the TMDL load allocation, expressed in the 1992 Yamhill Subbasin TMDL.

All five monitoring stations are located on larger streams. Four of the five stations exceeded the temperature status (last two years of available data). For the Middle Willamette, stations are not representative of the implementation statrigies identified in the Temperature TMDL for smaller streams.

Three monitoring stations (10363, 10929, and 10948) have sufficient data to assess status and/or trends of dissolved oxygen within the Yamhill AgWQ Management Area. None of the stations have continuous data and none display significant trends. All stations have exceedances of the water quality criteria within the last two years of data (2015-2017).

Three monitoring stations (10363, 10929, and 10948) have sufficient data to assess status and/or trends of E. coli within the Yamhill AgWQ Management Area. Stations 10363 and 10948 do not have enough data to calculate the geometric mean for determining water quality status during the entire timeframe (2000-2017). None of the monitoring stations had significant trends and all had at least one exceedance of the water quality criteria within the last two years of data (2015-2017).

Three monitoring stations (10363, 10929, and 10948) have sufficient data to assess status and/or trends of pH within the Yamhill AgWQ Management Area. The results for station 10363 have decreasing (degrading) trends and there are exceedances of the pH water quality criteria within the last two years (2015-2017) of data. Stations 10929 and 10948 do not have significant trends and do not have any exceedances of the water quality criteria during the last two years of data (2015-2017).

Four monitoring stations (USGS 14197900, USGS 14192015, 10363, and 10948) have sufficient data to calculate the temperature seven day average daily maximum (7DADM) and compare results to the water quality criteria within the Yamhill AgWQ Management Area. All monitoring stations have exceedances of the water quality criteria within the last two years of available data. None of the monitoring stations have significant trends. The USGS monitoring stations have continuous data.

Three monitoring stations (10363, 10929, and 10948) have sufficient data to assess status and trends of total phosphorus within the Yamhill AgWQ Management Area. No monitoring stations had results that represented significant trends. All monitoring stations had consistent exceedances of the TMDL load allocation of 0.07 mg/l through the entire timeframe.

Three monitoring stations (10363, 10929, and 10948) have sufficient data to assess trends of total suspended solids within the Yamhill AgWQ Management Area. Stations 10498 and 10929 had significant trends; station 10948 displays significant steady trends, while 10929 displays significant increasing (degrading) trends. Data was not compared to a TMDL load allocation since one has not been developed for the Middle Willamette or Yamill Subbasins.

Data collected at 14 stations were sufficient to assess status, and data from eight stations were sufficient to assess trends in dissolved oxygen concentration. Concentrations observed at 13 of the 14 status stations exceeded the applicable water quality criterion within the last two years. Trends in concentration were mixed, with three stations improving (10437, 11491, 11522), four stations degrading (10996, 10997, USGS-14309000, USGS-14317450), and one station steady (11484).

There were 10 monitoring stations within the Umpqua River AgWQ Management Area with data adequate to assess status and/or trends in E. coli concentration. One monitoring station (Station ID: 11484, South Umpqua at Days Creek Cutoff Rd. in Canyonville) had at least one exceedance of the water quality criterion within the last two years, and had a significant degrading trend. Three stations exceeded the criterion within the last two years, but had no significant trend. Six stations were found to meet the E. coli standard within the last two years. Of these six, one station was improving, three were degrading, and two exhibited no significant trend.
Data were not available in sufficient quantity to assess status and trends in Enterococcus concentration.

Data collected at 12 stations were sufficient to evaluate pH status and trends within the Umpqua River Agricultural Water Quality Management Area. Only four monitoring stations (10442, 10443, 11522 and USGS-14317450) had exceedances of the water quality criterion within the last two years. One of these four stations exhibited an improving trend, and the remaining three exhibited no significant trend. Eight stations met water quality criterion within the last two years. Two of these eight showed a significant improving trend, one station was steady across observations, and trends were not statistically significant at the remaining five stations.

All seven monitoring stations within the Umpqua River AgWQ Management Area with enough data to calculate status (as measured by 7DADM values) exceeded the applicable water quality criterion. Sufficient data to calculate trends were available at seven stations. Trends were degrading at three of these stations and not statistically significant at the remaining four stations.

Data collected at 10 stations were sufficient to evaluate trends in total phosphorous concentration. One station (10442, South Umpqua at Melrose Road) had a statistically significant improving trend. Six stations had a steady (flat) trend. The remaining three stations did not have a statistically significant trend.

Data collected at 10 stations were sufficient to evaluate trends in total suspended solids. Two stations (10451 and 10996) had a statistically significant degrading trend. Four stations had a steady (flat) trend. The remaining four stations did not have a statistically significant trend.

Grab samples may not provide a complete characterization of water quality for parameters that fluctuate on a daily basis (e.g., temperature, DO, pH). For this reason continuous data are preferred and should be considered when monitoring these parameters in the future.

This report is best used as a summary and statistical analysis of the status and trends in water quality data collected throughout the Umpqua River AgWQ Management Area. Interpretation of results will require knowledge of local conditions known to affect the observed water quality conditions at individual sites.

There are seven monitoring stations within the Curry County AgWQ Management Area that have sufficient data to assess status and/or trends of dissolved oxygen data with regards to the applicable water quality criterion. Dissolved oxygen concentrations observed at six stations (10533, 10537, 11483, 11493, 11905, 12590) exceeded the water quality criterion within the last two years. Observed trends were mixed, with two stations improving (11905, 10533) and 5 stations with no statistically significant trend.

There are seven monitoring stations within the Curry County AgWQ Management that had sufficient data to assess status and/or trends in E. coli concentrations. These seven monitoring stations (10414, 10533, 10537, 11483, 11493, 11905, 12590), do not have exceedances of the water quality criterion within the last two years, but six of the stations exhibit a significant degrading trend, except for station 12590, which exhibits an improving trend.

Enterococcus data collected at one station (31555) was sufficient to assess status and trend. Enterococcus concentrations observed meets the water quality standard within the last two years. There is a statistically significant steady trend.

There were seven monitoring stations within the Curry County AgWQ Management Area that had sufficient data to assess status and/or trends of pH. All seven of these monitoring stations (10414, 10533, 10537, 11483, 11493, 11905, 12590) do not have exceedances of the water quality criterion within the last two years. Two of the stations (10533, 11905) exhibit a steady trend, one station (10537) an improving trend, and the remaining stations exhibit no significant trend.

There was one monitoring station within the Curry County AgWQ Management Area that had sufficient data to calculate status (7DADM) and evaluate against the applicable water quality criterion. This station (USGS-14372300), had an exceedance of the water quality criterion within the last two years, but does exhibit a significant trend.

Data collected at ten stations were sufficient to evaluate trends in total phosphorus concentration within the Curry County AgWQ Management Area. Two stations (10414, 11905), had a significantly steady trend, one station (28303), had a significantly degrading trend, and the remaining seven stations (10533, 10537, 11483, 11493, 12590, 23753, 30670), did not have a significant trend.

There were seven monitoring stations within the Curry County AgWQ Management Area that had sufficient data to evaluate trends in total suspended solids. The two stations (10537, 11483) had a statistically significant steady trend, one station (10414) had a statistically significant degrading trend, and the remaining four stations (10533, 11493, 11905, 12590), did not have a significant trend.

One monitoring station has sufficient data to calculate the 7DADM for temperature to assess against the applicable water quality standards. Collection of additional continuous temperature data would be useful to determine status and trends.

DEQ recommends continued sampling for E. coli, dissolved oxygen, total phosphorus and total suspended solids at all stations that are currently in the sampling cycle to support status assessment and development of a data record sufficient for trend assessment.

DEQ recommends continued sampling for Enterococcus only at stations designated for coastal contact recreation or shellfish harvesting to support status assessment and development of a data record sufficient for trend assessment.

Data collected at three stations (Deschutes River Park [10411], Deschutes River at Hwy. 26 [10506], and Fifteenmile Creek [28333]) were sufficient to assess both status and trends in dissolved oxygen concentration. Concentrations observed at these stations exceeded the water quality standard within the last two years. Trends in concentration were not statistically significant. Data collected at one additional station (WARMSPRINGS09-Sherars Falls) was sufficient to calculate an improving trend, but was insufficient to calculate a status.

There were three monitoring stations within the Lower Deschutes AgWQ Management with data adequate to assess status and trends in E. coli concentration. One monitoring station (Fifteenmile Creek [28333]) had at least one exceedance of the water quality standard within the last two years, but exhibited no significant trend. Two stations (Deschutes River Park [10411] and Deschutes River at Hwy. 26 [10506]) were found to meet the E. coli standard within the last two years, and both exhibited no significant trend.
Data were not available in sufficient quantity to assess status and trends in Enterococcus concentration.

Data collected at four stations were sufficient to evaluate pH status and/or trends within the Lower Deschutes Agricultural Water Quality Management Area. Data collected at three monitoring stations (Deschutes River Park [10411], Deschutes River at Hwy. 26 [10506], and Fifteenmile Creek [28333]) exceeded the water quality standard within the last two years. Of the three exceeding stations, two (Deschutes River Park [10411] and Deschutes River at Hwy. 26 [10506]) exhibited no significant trends, and one (Fifteenmile Creek [28333]) exhibited an improving trend. Status at one last station (WARMSPRINGS09-Sherars Falls) was undetermined, with no statistically significant trend.

Data collected at one station (Deschutes River at Moody [USGS-14103000]) was sufficient to evaluate temperature status and/or trends (as measured by 7DADM values) within the Lower Deschutes Agricultural Water Quality Management Area. Measurements exceeded the applicable water quality criterion and the trend was undetermined.

Data collected at three stations were sufficient to evaluate trends in total phosphorous concentration. Two of the three stations (Deschutes River Park [10411] and Deschutes River at Hwy. 26 [10506]) had a statistically significant steady (flat) trend. The remaining one station (Fifteenmile Creek [28333]) exhibited no significant trend.

Data collected at three stations were sufficient to evaluate trends in total suspended solid concentration. One of the three stations (Deschutes River Park [10411]) had a statistically significant degrading trend. The remaining two stations (Deschutes River at Hwy. 26 [10506] and Fifteenmile Creek [28333]) did not have a statistically significant trend.

Grab samples may not provide a complete characterization of water quality for parameters that fluctuate on a daily basis (e.g., DO and pH). For this reason continuous data are preferred and should be considered when monitoring these parameters in the future.

This report is best used as a summary and statistical analysis of the status and trends in water quality data collected throughout the Lower Deschutes AgWQ Management Area. Interpretation of results will require knowledge of local conditions known to affect the observed water quality conditions at individual sites.

There are seven stations that have sufficient data to assess status and/or trends for Dissolved oxygen. Stations 11201, 10332, 10611, and 10801 showed no exceedances in the last two years while stations 11321 and USGS-14211720 had at least one. Stations10332, 10611, 10801, and 33613 showed a significant improving trend in DO while USGS-14211720 had a degrading trend. No significant DO trend was determined in the available data for stations 11321 and 11201.

There was sufficient E. Coli data available to assess status and/or trends for five stations in the Lower Willamette Ag Water Quality Management Area. Stations 11201, 10332, 10611, and 10801 had no exceedances within the data available. Station 11321 had at least one exceedance. An improving trend in E. Coli data was found at stations 10332, 10611, 10801, and 11321 where no significant trend could be determined at station 11201.
There were no stations with sufficient data to assess status or trends for Enterococcus.

Eight stations had enough data available to assess status and/or trends for pH. Stations 10332, 10611, and 11321 had no exceedances within the last two years while 11201, 10801, and USGS-14211720 had at least one exceedance. Stations 10332, 10611, 10801, 33613, and 28712 all showed a decreasing pH trend. The only station with an increasing trend was USGS-14211720 and stations 11321 and 11201 showed no significant trend for pH.

Status and/or trend was able to be determined at seven stations within the Lower Willamette Ag Water Quality Management Area. Stations USGS-14211720, USGS-14211400, USGS-14211499, USGS-14211500, and USGS-14211550 all exceeded the water quality standard for temperature in the last two years. USGS-14211546 was the only station that showed a significant improving trend. USGS-14211400, USGS-14211499, and USGS-14211500 all had degrading trends. No other significant temperature trends were able to be determined.

Trends in total phosphorus were determined at six stations within the Lower Willamette Ag Water Quality Management Area. Significant improving trends were determined at stations 11321, 11201, 10332, 10611, and USGS-14211720 while station 10801s trend was steady.
Only station 11201 showed a significant degrading trend for total suspended solids. No other significant trends were able to be determined.

Data collected at two stations (12012, 33603) were sufficient to assess both status and trends in dissolved oxygen concentration. Concentrations observed at these stations exceeded the water quality standard within the last two years, and trends in concentration were not statistically significant. Data collected at one additional station (13141) were sufficient to calculate an improving trend, but those data were insufficient to calculate a status.

There were two monitoring stations within the Hood River AgWQ Management with data adequate to assess status and trends in E. coli concentration. One monitoring station (33603) had at least one exceedance of the water quality standard within the last two years, but exhibited a degrading trend. The other station (12012) was found to meet the E. coli standard within the last two years, but exhibited no significant trend.
Data were not available in sufficient quantity to assess status and trends in Enterococcus concentration.

Data collected at two stations were sufficient to evaluate both pH status and trends. Data collected at one of those monitoring stations (12012) met the water quality standard within the last two years and exhibited a degrading trend. Data collected at the other station (33603) met the water quality standard within the last two years and exhibited no significant trend. Data collected at three other stations (11972, 13141, and 30174) were sufficient for trend assessment but not status. All three stations had a statistically significant degrading trend.
Data were not available in sufficient quantity to assess status and trends in temperature.

Data collected at two stations were sufficient to evaluate trends in total phosphorous concentration. One of the two stations (12012) had a statistically significant improving trend. The remaining one station (33603) exhibited no significant trend.

Data collected at three stations were sufficient to evaluate trends in total suspended solid concentration. One of the three stations (33603) had a statistically significant degrading trend. The remaining two stations (12012 and 13141) did not have a statistically significant trend.

Grab samples may not provide a complete characterization of water quality for parameters that fluctuate on a daily basis (e.g., DO and pH). For this reason continuous data are preferred and should be considered when monitoring these parameters in the future.

This report is best used as a summary and statistical analysis of the status and trends in water quality data collected throughout the Hood River AgWQ Management Area. Interpretation of results will require knowledge of local conditions known to affect the observed water quality conditions at individual sites.

Stream/river data collected at four stations were sufficient to assess both status and trends in dissolved oxygen concentration. Concentrations observed at two of these stations (10729, 11050) exceeded the water quality standard within the last two years, while the remaining two (10730, 36783) met the water quality standard within the last two years. One station (11050) showed a degrading trend while the remaining three stations exhibited no significant trend. Drain data collected at two stations were sufficient to assess both status and trends in dissolved oxygen concentration. Both stations (15540, 15541) met the water quality standard within the last two years. Station 15541 showed a degrading trend while the other station exhibited no significant trend.

Stream/river data collected at four stations were sufficient to assess status in E. coli concentration. Two stations (10729, 36783) exceeded the water quality standard, while the remaining two (10730, 11050) met the water quality standard within the last two years. Two stations (10729, 1119USBR_WQX-MAL218) showed an improving trend, while the remaining four stations (10730, 11050, 1119USBR_WQX-OWY110 , 36783) exhibited no significant trend. Drain data collected at five stations were sufficient to assess status in E. coli concentration. All five stations (1119USBR_WQX-OWY301,  1119USBR_WQX-OWY304, 1119USBR_WQX-OWY307, 1119USBR_WQX-OWY310, 1119USBR_WQX-OWY313) exceeded the water quality standard within the last two years. Two stations (1119USBR_WQX-MAL214, 1119USBR_WQX-MAL216) showed an improving trend, while the remaining stations did not have sufficient data to calculate a trend.
A status or trend assessment was not made for _Enterococcus_ because the coastal water contact recreation use criteria does not apply in the Owyhee.

Stream/river data collected at four stations (10729, 10730, 11050, 36783) were sufficient to evaluate both pH status and trends. All four stations met the water quality standard within the last two years. Station 10729 showed a steady trend while the remaining stations exhibited no significant trend. Drain data collected at two stations (15540, 15541) were sufficient to evaluate both pH status and trends. Both stations met the water quality standard within the last two years. Station 15541 showed a degrading trend while the other station exhibited no significant trend.
Data were not available in sufficient quantity to assess status and trends in temperature.

Stream/ river data collected at four stations were sufficient to assess status. All four stations (10729, 10730, 11050, 36783) had total concentrations that exceeded the 0.07 mg/L Snake River - Hells-Canyon Sediment TMDL targets. Three stations (10729, 1119USBR_WQX-MAL218, 1119USBR_WQX-OWY110) showed an improving trend while the remaining station did not have statistically significant trend. Drain data collected at five stations were sufficient to assess status. All five stations (1119USBR_WQX-OWY301, 1119USBR_WQX-OWY304, 1119USBR_WQX-OWY307, 1119USBR_WQX-OWY310, 1119USBR_WQX-OWY313) had total concentrations that exceeded the 0.07 mg/L Snake River - Hells-Canyon Sediment TMDL targets from May to September. One station (1119USBR_WQX-MAL214) showed a degrading trend, while the remaining either did not have statistically significant trend or did not have sufficient data to calculate a trend.

Stream/river data collected at four stations were sufficient to assess status. One station (10729) had monthly mean total suspended sediment concentrations that exceeded the 50 mg/L Snake River - Hells-Canyon Sediment TMDL targets from May to September, while three stations (10730, 11050, 36783) did not exceed the target in the last two whole years. Two stations (10729, 1119USBR_WQX-OWY110) had an improving trend. The remaining two stations (10730, 1119USBR_WQX-MAL218)  did not have statistically significant trends. Drain data collected at five stations were sufficient to assess status. All five stations (1119USBR_WQX-OWY301, 1119USBR_WQX-OWY304, 1119USBR_WQX-OWY307, 1119USBR_WQX-OWY310, 1119USBR_WQX-OWY313) had monthly mean total suspended sediment concentrations that exceeded the 50 mg/L Snake River - Hells-Canyon Sediment TMDL targets. The station on Penny Drain (1119USBR_WQX-MAL216) had a degrading trend. The one remaining station (1119USBR_WQX-MAL214) did not have statistically significant trend.

The dissolved oxygen and pH analyses are based on grab samples and may not provide a complete characterization of water quality for parameters that fluctuate on a daily basis. For this reason continuous data are preferred and should be considered when monitoring these parameters in the future.

This report is best used as a summary and statistical analysis of the status and trends in water quality data collected throughout the Owyhee Agricultural Water Quality Management Area. Interpretation of results will require knowledge of local conditions known to affect the observed water quality conditions at individual sites.

Data collected at four monitoring stations were sufficient to assess status and/or trends of E. coli concentration. E. coli concentrations observed at three stations (10404, 10406, 11489) attained the freshwater contact recreation criterion within the last two whole years. Station 12005 did not attain the freshwater contact recreation criterion within the last two whole years. Three stations (10404, 10406, 12005) have degrading trends, and station 114896 did not have a statistically significant trend.
The Enterococcus coastal water contact recreation criteria does not apply in the Umatilla so an assessment was not made.

Data collected at four monitoring stations were sufficient to assess status and/or trends of pH. pH observed at three stations (10404, 10406, 12005) had excursions of the pH criterion within the last two whole years. Station 11489 attained the pH criterion within the last two whole years. Three stations (10404, 11489, 12005) have improving trends, and station 10406 did not have a statistically significant trend.
Continuous temperature data were not available in sufficient quantity to assess status and trends.

Data collected at four stations were sufficient to evaluate trends in total phosphorous concentration. One of the three stations (10406) had a statistically significant steady trend. The remaining three stations (10404, 11489, 12005) did not have a significant trend.

Data collected at four stations were sufficient to assess status and trends in total suspended solid concentration. Two of the four stations (11489, 12005) exceeded the instream TSS targets established in the Umatilla Subbasin Sediment TMDL and had degrading trends. Station 10404 also exceeded the TSS target but had an improving trend. Station 10406 met the TMDL target within that last two whole years and has exhibited a steady trend.

There was insufficient data to calculate the seven day average daily maximum stream temperature to assess against the applicable temperature criteria. DEQ recommends collection of continuous temperature data as described in the Umatilla Subbasin TMDL long term monitoring plan.

DEQ recommends continued sampling for E. coli, dissolved oxygen, pH, and total suspended solids at existing stations and adding new stations consistent with the Umatilla Subbasin TMDL long term monitoring plan.

Data collected at six stations were sufficient to assess status, and data from 11 stations were sufficient to assess trends in dissolved oxygen concentration. Concentrations observed at all six of the ?status? stations exceeded the water quality standard within the last two years. Trends in concentration were mixed, with five stations improving (10393, 10596, 11486, 13570, and 13574), and six stations with no significant trend (11485, 14018, 34827, 34828, 34829, and 34830).

There were 10 monitoring stations within the Coos-Coquille AgWQ Management with data adequate to assess status and/or trends in E. coli concentration. Two monitoring stations (10393 and 11486) had at least one exceedance of the water quality standard within the last two years, but exhibited no significant trend. Seven stations were found to meet the E. coli standard within the last two years. Of these seven, one station was improving (13570) and two exhibited no significant trend (10596 and 13574). Four stations (33922, CTCLUSI_WQX-CTCEDWQ, CTCLUSI_WQX-CTCNSWQ, and CTCLUSI_WQX-CTCTDWQ) that met the standard did not have enough data to determine a trend. The remaining station (11485) had an undetermined status and exhibited no significant trend.
Data were not available in sufficient quantity to assess status and trends in Enterococcus concentration.

Data collected at 10 stations were sufficient to evaluate pH status and/or trends within the Coos-Coquille Agricultural Water Quality Management Area. Data collected at three monitoring stations (10393, 13570, and 13574) met the water quality standard within the last two years but exhibited no significant trend. Data collected at one station (10596) met the standard and had a steady trend. One station (11486) met the standard but had a degrading trend. One station (33922) met the standard with an undetermined trend. Three stations (11485, 14018, and 34830) had an undetermined status, but showed a degrading trend; one last station (34829) had an undetermined status and no statistically significant trend.
Data were not available in sufficient quantity to assess status and trends in temperature.

Data collected at nine stations were sufficient to evaluate trends in total phosphorous concentration. Three stations (10393, 10596, and 13574) had a statistically significant steady (flat) trend. The remaining six stations (11485, 11486, 13570, 14018, 34829, and 34830) exhibited no significant trend.

Data collected at six stations were sufficient to evaluate trends in total suspended solids. Three stations (10393, 11485, and 11486) had a statistically significant degrading trend. The remaining three stations (10596, 13570, and 13574) did not have a statistically significant trend.

Grab samples may not provide a complete characterization of water quality for parameters that fluctuate on a daily basis (e.g., DO and pH). For this reason continuous data are preferred and should be considered when monitoring these parameters in the future.

This report is best used as a summary and statistical analysis of the status and trends in water quality data collected throughout the Coos-Coquille AgWQ Management Area. Interpretation of results will require knowledge of local conditions known to affect the observed water quality conditions at individual sites.

Knowledge of local conditions is especially important in the interpretation of trends. Some real, meaningful trends may be obscured by a lack of statistical significance. Conversely, some other statistically significant trends are can be the result of having a high number of observations at these stations, rather than any meaningful change in water quality at these stations.

AgArea: Upper Mainstem and South Fork John Day River
conclusion: Concentrations at both stations exceeded the water quality standard within the last two years. An improving trend was observed at the John Day station, and no statistically significant trend was observed at the South Fork station.

AgArea: Upper Mainstem and South Fork John Day River
conclusion: Concentrations at both stations exceeded the water quality standard within the last two years. A degrading trend was observed at the John Day station, and no statistically significant trend was observed at the South Fork station.

AgArea: Upper Mainstem and South Fork John Day River
conclusion: Not applicable to this watershed.

AgArea: Upper Mainstem and South Fork John Day River
conclusion: Concentrations at both stations met the water quality standard within the last two years. No statistically significant trend was observed at the John Day station, and a steady (flat) trend was observed at the South Fork station.

AgArea: Upper Mainstem and South Fork John Day River
conclusion: Data were not available in sufficient quantity to evaluate status or trends in temperature.

AgArea: Upper Mainstem and South Fork John Day River
conclusion: Data were not available in sufficient quantity to evaluate trends in total phosphorous concentration. Status was not evaluated because no standard for total phosphorous exists in these watersheds.

AgArea: Upper Mainstem and South Fork John Day River
conclusion: Degrading trends (i.e., increasing TSS concentration) in were observed at both stations. Status was not evaluated because no standard for TSS exists in these watersheds.

AgArea: Upper Mainstem and South Fork John Day River
conclusion: Grab samples may not provide a complete characterization of water quality for parameters that fluctuate on a daily basis (e.g., DO and pH). For this reason continuous data are preferred and should be considered when monitoring these parameters in the future.

AgArea: Upper Mainstem and South Fork John Day River
conclusion: This report is best used as a summary and statistical analysis of the status and trends in water quality data collected throughout the Upper Mainstem and South Fork John Day River AgWQ Management Area. Interpretation of results will require knowledge of local conditions known to affect the observed water quality conditions at individual sites.

Data collected at seven stations were sufficient to assess status. Two of the seven stations (10339, 14008) had dissolved oxygen concentrations that met the criteria in the last two years. The remaining five stations (11233, 13070, USGS-14209710, USGS-14210000, USGS-14211010) had dissolved oxygen concentrations that exceeded the criteria in the last two years. Data collected at seven stations were sufficient to assess trends. Three of the seven stations (10339, 11233, 14008) had an improving trend. Three of the seven stations (USGS-14209710, USGS-14210000, USGS-14211010) had a degrading trend. The remaining station (13070) did not have a statistically significant trend.

Data collected at four stations were sufficient to assess status. Three of the four stations (11233, 13070, 14008) had _E. coli_ concentrations that met the criteria in the last two years. The remaining one stations (10339) had _E. coli_ concentrations that exceeded the criteria in the last two years. Data collected at four stations were sufficient to assess trends. One of the four stations (14008) had a steady trend. One of the four stations (10339) had a degrading trend. The remaining two stations (11233, 13070) did not have statistically significant trends.
Data were not available in sufficient quantity to assess status. Data were not available in the last two years to assess trend.

Data collected at seven stations were sufficient to assess status. Four of the seven stations (10339, 11233, 13070, USGS-14210000) had pH that met the criteria in the last two years. The remaining three stations (14008, USGS-14209710, USGS-14211010) had pH that exceeded the criteria in the last two years. Data collected at seven stations were sufficient to assess trends. One of the seven stations (USGS-14209710) had an improving trend. One of the seven stations (USGS-14210000) had a steady trend. Two of the seven stations (10339, 13070) had a degrading trend. The remaining three stations (11233, 14008, USGS-14211010) did not have statistically significant trends.

Data collected at three stations were sufficient to assess status. All three stations (USGS-14209710, USGS-14210000, USGS-14211010) exceeded the temperature criteria in the last two years. Data collected at three stations were sufficient to assess trends. All three stations had a degrading trend.

Data were not available in sufficient quantity to assess status. Data collected at four stations were sufficient to assess trends. One of the four stations (10339) had an improving trend. Two of the four stations (11233, 13070) had a steady trend. The remaining station (14008) did not have a statistically significant trend.

Data were not available in sufficient quantity to assess status. Data collected at four stations were sufficient to assess trends. Two of the four stations (13070, 14008) had a steady trend. The remaining two stations (10339, 11233) did not have statistically significant trends.

Grab samples may not provide a complete characterization of water quality for parameters that fluctuate on a daily basis                              (e.g., DO and pH). For this reason continuous data are preferred and should be considered when monitoring these parameters                             in the future.

This report is best used as a summary and statistical analysis of the status and trends in water quality data collected                               throughout the Clackamas Agricultural Water Quality Management Area. Interpretation of results will require knowledge of                              local conditions known to affect the observed water quality conditions at individual sites.
